CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, December 16, 1961, pg. 2, reads: "Part of Bishop's Plans? - This ornate, four-story building, located at 1329 Locust St., in shadow of Mercy Hospital, is home for more than 20 Negroes, many of them elderly pensioners displaced during redevelopment in the Lowe Hill. Though rated as sub-standard when inspected earlier this year, when it was under the management of DePaul Smith, it will be brought up to specifications if Bishop D. H. Harris follows through on his plans to make it one of the 'Triumph Rescue Homes for the Needy.. - Harris Photos."  Portion of accompanying article reads: "Bishop D. Harris Explains Program?  Editor's note: While Pittsburgh (The Renaissance City) proudly displays its renovation of the Golden Triangle, highlights by the $22 million Civic Arena, to its many citizens and visitors, and maps magnificent plans for 'urban renewal, it has 'swept under the rug its 'dregs of human misery' - those displaced persons, a majority of whom are Negroes, who either have not been relocated or are unable to find suitable housing on their own.  Crack Courier reporter Phyl Garland has gone behind the scenes to interview and write about these 'Prisoners of the Ghetto' and their vicious 'jailer.'  This is the fourth in a series of articles which The Courier offers its readers..."
TitMainTitle: Four story stone building with wrought iron balconies, 1329 Locust Street, Oakland
